segments.text: That night the theatre was unusually crowded. A portly manager—whom some might describe in less tasteful terms—met the arriving guests at the door with a broad, oily smile. He escorted them to their box with exaggerated, pompous gestures while his loud, impassioned speech filled the foyer. Dorian Gray silently seethed with loathing for him—as if expecting Miranda but receiving instead a grotesque Caliban—while Lord Henry expressed a curious admiration, extolling the manager’s bold, if bankrupt, discovery of genius. Meanwhile, Basil Hallward observed the faces in the pit, the air oppressive with heat and the brilliant sunlight blazing like a monstrous dahlia. Youngsters in the gallery shed their coats and mingled with tawdry girls as laughter and the pop of corks from the bar set the evening in motion.
What a place to find one’s divinity in!

Yes! It was here I found her, and she is divine beyond all living things. When she acts, you will forget everything. These crude people, with their coarse features and brutal gestures, transform completely when she steps on the stage. They sit in silence, weeping and laughing as she wills them—they become as responsive as a violin, their souls stirred, as if of the same flesh and blood as my own.

voice_traits.accent: elegant with a hint of Romantic flair

segments.text: The same flesh and blood as one’s self! Oh, I hope not!

voice_traits.voice_affect: breezy with a touch of mischief

segments.text: Don’t pay any attention to him, Dorian. I understand what you mean, and I believe in her. Anyone you love must be marvelous, and any girl who moves you thus is noble and rare. If she can breathe a soul into lifeless hearts, stir beauty in lives so dismal, and lend them tears for unseen sorrows, then she is worthy of all adoration—the adoration of you and the world.

Thanks, Basil. I knew you would understand me. Harry is so cynical, he terrifies me. But here is the orchestra—it’s dreadful, lasting only a few minutes. Then the curtain will rise, and you shall see the girl to whom I intend to devote all that is good in me.

A quarter of an hour later, amidst a tumultuous applause, Sibyl Vane stepped onto the stage. Her beauty was breathtaking—a shy, almost fawn-like grace with startled eyes and a delicate blush. As she glanced at the enthusiastic crowd, her lips trembled. Basil Hallward leaped to his feet in applause while Dorian, as if lost in a dream, sat motionless, captivated by her. Lord Henry peered through his opera-glass, murmuring, 'Charming! charming!'

The scene shifted to a grand hall reminiscent of Capulet’s estate, where Romeo in his pilgrim’s attire entered with Mercutio and other companions. As the band started a few lively bars, the dance began. Through the throng of scruffy characters, Sibyl moved as though from a more refined realm—swaying like a plant in water, her graceful neck comparable to a white lily, and her hands appearing as elegant as carved ivory.
Good pilgrim, you do wrong your hand too much, Which mannerly devotion shows in this; For saints have hands that pilgrims’ hands do touch, And palm to palm is holy palmers’ kiss.

Despite the technical beauty of her voice, everything about her performance felt false. The artificial tone robbed her verse of any genuine passion, leaving Dorian pale, puzzled, and burdened by anxiety. Those around him shared his disappointment, quietly judging her competence—except for the steadfast hope that her next performance, the famed balcony scene of the second act, might restore her true brilliance.

As the night deepened, Sibyl’s stage presence was a mix of undeniable charm and unbearable theatrical exaggeration. Emerging in the moonlight, she remained beautiful yet painfully stage-bound. Her artificial gestures and overemphasized declamations, including lines like 'Thou knowest the mask of night is on my face…', were delivered with the strained precision of a novice reciting in a schoolroom, robbing the words of all genuine emotion.

Although I joy in thee, I have no joy of this contract to-night: It is too rash, too unadvised, too sudden; Too like the lightning, which doth cease to be Ere one can say, “It lightens.” Sweet, good-night! This bud of love by summer’s ripening breath May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet.

segments.text: The play’s disastrous nature grew evident as even the uneducated crowd in the pit began to chatter, whistle, and express their discontent. The angry manager stamped about in fury as the only one unmoved by the failure was Sibyl herself, her performance now deemed a catastrophe by her closest observers.
She is quite beautiful, Dorian, but she can’t act. Let us go.

segments.text: I am going to see the play through. I am awfully sorry that I have made you waste an evening, Harry. I apologize to you both.

segments.text: My dear Dorian, I should think Miss Vane was ill. We will come another night.

segments.text: I wish she were ill. But she appears simply callous and cold. Last night she was a great artist; tonight, she is merely an ordinary actress.

segments.text: Don’t talk like that about anyone you love, Dorian. Love is a more wonderful thing than art. They’re both merely forms of imitation. But really, come with Basil and me; let’s leave this bad acting behind. Besides, if your wife were to act, it would hardly matter. She is very lovely—and if she’s as naïve about life as she is about acting, she will be a delightful experience. There are only two kinds of people: those who know absolutely everything and those who know absolutely nothing. My dear boy, don’t look so tragic!

segments.text: Go away, Harry! I want to be alone. Basil, you must go. Ah—can’t you see that my heart is breaking?

segments.text: The curtain rose on the third act, but the play only grew more tedious. The audience trickled away, leaving nearly empty benches and a dismal, echoing stage. In his despondence, Dorian slipped away into the greenroom where he found Sibyl, standing alone with a look of triumph and a secret fire in her eyes.
How badly I acted tonight, Dorian!

segments.text: Horribly! It was dreadful. Are you ill? You have no idea what it was… what I suffered.

segments.text: Dorian… Dorian, you should have understood. But you understand now, don’t you?

segments.text: Understand what?
Why I was so bad tonight. Why I shall always be bad. Why I shall never act well again.
You are ill, I suppose. When you are ill you shouldn’t act—you make yourself ridiculous. My friends were bored; I was bored.

segments.text: Yes, you have killed my love. You used to stir my imagination; now you don’t even stir my curiosity. I loved you because you were marvelous, possessed genius and intellect—because you shaped the dreams of great poets and gave substance to art. You’ve thrown it all away. You are shallow and stupid. My God, how mad I was to love you! What a fool I have been. You are nothing to me now! I will never see you again—I will never think of you, never mention your name. Once, you were everything. Now, I wish I’d never laid eyes on you. You have spoiled the romance of my life.

segments.text: Overcome by sympathy and enervation, Sibyl sank to the floor in a fit of passionate sobbing. Dorian, though his eyes shone with a pale light, regarded her with a cool, almost disdainful detachment. Her tearful display, once moving, now seemed absurd—a theatrically melodramatic outpouring that no longer stirred his heart.

Shortly thereafter, Dorian slipped away from the greenroom. He wandered through dimly lit streets past gaunt archways and derelict houses. The harsh laughter of women and the curse-filled chatter of inebriated drunks mingled with the eerie calls of street vendors. Before he knew it, dawn was breaking over Covent Garden—a scene of quiet beauty and renewal that contrasted sharply with his inner turmoil.

In the early morning light Dorian hailed a hansom, and upon returning home he lingered on his doorstep, contemplating the silent square. The rising sun, the gleaming roofs, and the curling chimney smoke blended with his scattered thoughts about last night’s revelations.

Inside his lavish entrance hall, adorned in curious Renaissance tapestries, Dorian’s eyes were drawn to the portrait Basil had painted of him. In the gentle, diffused light the portrait displayed a subtle yet disturbing change—a trace of cruelty around the mouth, as if the canvas itself now bore the burden of his sins and passions. He questioned his own past wish for eternal youth, and the portrait’s altered expression haunted him with its silent indictment.

Torn between regret and resolve, Dorian sat contemplating the implications. Though his heart felt both hardened and tender, he vowed silently to resist further transgressions. Yet even as he blocked out the portrait with a large screen, its cruel smile and altered features remained a visible emblem of his inner conscience—a reminder of the passion that once stirred him and that might, someday, beckon him back to love.
